title: Sydney prices regain a third of what was lost
text:
"Sydney's median house price lost just over $167,000 during the downturn and it's gained just over $49,000 of that, so it's almost one-third of the price fall gained back so it is a pretty remarkable start to the recovery for houses," Domain senior research analyst Nicola Powell said.

"Falling interest rates and the expectation of further cash rate cuts next year, you've got the relaxation of lending standards, we also had the re-election of the Coalition government so there were no changes to negative gearing.

"And I think all of these factors have helped to bolster that recovery," Dr Powell said.

'Pent-up demand'

The new quarterly data from Domain Group showed a similar trend to CoreLogic's home value index, which is released monthly and has recorded property values rising in Sydney and Melbourne every month since June.

Dr Powell said the length of the downturn had also likely contributed to the sudden recovery, because over that period there had been a build-up of eager buyers waiting on the sidelines for the market to recover.

"There were so many unknowns with firstly what was going to happen with interest rates, and the tightening of lending as well, so some buyers were locked out of the market," she said.

Advertisement

"There is an element of pent-up demand and we've now seen mortgage lending rise in NSW so we can probably assume the majority of that is going to be Sydney."

According to the latest ABS figures, investor home loans grew at their fastest pace in almost three years in August and banks are making a play for their business.

This week Westpac halved its deposit requirements for interest-only investment loans from 20 per cent to 10 per cent following ANZ's similar move in March.

House prices fell 4.8 per cent in Newcastle and 7.8 per cent in Wollongong over the year.
description: Sydney's median house price has regained almost one-third of what was lost during the 18-month downturn in the past three months.
